citations.narrative:
The Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) presented at time of inspection did not have a plan for vaccinating for rabies,
mention the sampling and treatment of parasites (including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia and heartworm) nor did it
include a schedule for their sampling. It did not mention a schedule for when preventative care and treatment (including
eyes, skin, teeth, and nails) would occur. It did state that the attending veterinarian would inspect the premises and that
they would complete a head-to-tail exam on each adult dog on a yearly basis, but no documentation that this occurred
was available at time of inspection.
An appropriate PVC must include a plan to vaccinate for rabies, sampling for parasites, and include a preventative care
plan. An appropriate PVC must be developed and followed to ensure the health and well-being of the dogs.
The applicant must add to the PVC: a plan for vaccinating for rabies, a plan for having the dogs sampled for parasites,
and a schedule for preventative care. The applicant must also have available documentation to demonstrate that the PVC
is being followed.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 8th, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) presented at time of inspection did not have a plan for vaccinating for rabies, 
mention the sampling and treatment of parasites (including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia and heartworm) nor did it 
include a schedule for their sampling. It did not mention a schedule for when preventative care and treatment (including 
eyes, skin, teeth, and nails) would occur. It did state that the attending veterinarian would inspect the premises and that 
they would complete a head-to-tail exam on each adult dog on a yearly basis, but no documentation that this occurred 
was available at time of inspection. 
An appropriate PVC must include a plan to vaccinate for rabies, sampling for parasites, and include a preventative care 
plan. An appropriate PVC must be developed and followed to ensure the health and well-being of the dogs.  
The applicant must add to the PVC: a plan for vaccinating for rabies, a plan for having the dogs sampled for parasites, 
and a schedule for preventative care. The applicant must also have available documentation to demonstrate that the PVC 
is being followed. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 8th, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
